column2: COVID-19 negative certification required for entering the country. If you’re not fully vaccinated, you will need a negative PCR test to enter or travel through Kazakhstan. The PCR certificate must be issued within three days prior to arrival in Kazakhstan.
column3:
Self-isolation at own accommodation- subject to PCR. If you’re travelling to Kazakhstan, you do not need to quarantine when you arrive, if you have a negative PCR test certificate.
Travellers entering Kazakhstan who test positive for coronavirus currently need to self-isolate for 10 days.
column4: Foreign nationals with certificate proof of vaccination, do not need a PCR test prior to entering Kazakhstan.
column5:
Latest News: Authorities ease temporary COVID-19 travel restrictions (Astana Times, 09.02.2022).

International Restrictions:
*All travellers: Some foreign nationals no longer need a visa to enter Kazakhstan. But this could change at short notice if the COVID-19 situation changes.
You will need to provide details of where you are staying in Kazakhstan and confirm you will abide by all coronavirus restrictions.
If you’re fully vaccinated: If you’re fully vaccinated, you can enter Kazakhstan without needing to test or quarantine.
Proof of vaccination status: You must present proof that you have been fully vaccinated to enter Kazakhstan.
Kazakhstan will accept the proof of COVID-19 vaccination record. Your appointment card from vaccination centres is not designed to be used as proof of vaccination and should not be used to demonstrate your vaccine status. If you are vaccinated in Kazakhstan and are using a Kazakh vaccination passport for entry your last dose (or booster) must be within the last six months.
If you’re not fully vaccinated: If you’re not fully vaccinated, you will need a negative PCR test to enter or travel through Kazakhstan. The PCR certificate must be issued within three days prior to arrival in Kazakhstan.
If you’re travelling to Kazakhstan, you do not need to quarantine when you arrive, if you have a negative PCR test certificate.
Travellers entering Kazakhstan who test positive for coronavirus currently need to self-isolate for 10 days. Those needing medical assistance may be confined in state facilities.
If you need further information about entry requirements, contact the local immigration authorities or the nearest Kazakh embassy. You should also check with your airline or travel company for the latest information.
If you’ve had COVID-19 in the past year: If you’re not fully vaccinated but have tested positive for COVID-19 in the last year you can enter Kazakhstan, but still require a PCR test prior to entry.
Children and young people: Children under 5 do not need a PCR test to enter Kazakhstan.
If you’re transiting through Kazakhstan: Transiting is when you pass through one country on the way to your final destination.
Transiting through Kazakhstan is permitted for travellers who meet the requirements of their final destination.
If you are transiting through Kazakhstan on your way to another country and will be passing through immigration (sometimes known as a layover), for example to stay in a hotel for a flight the next day, you need to follow normal entry procedures.
*Exemptions: Children under 5 are exempted from the requirement to present a negative PCR test on arrival. Some official government delegations are exempt from PCR testing requirements


Internal Restrictions:
*Travel in Kazakhstan: There are occasionally local restrictions in place, particularly in the south due to recent unrest. Breaches of regulations can result in fines or eventually imprisonment
Accommodation: Most hotels are open, although some close at short notice due to low demand.
Public places and services: Almost all Covid restrictions have been lifted, other than in medical facilities, where face coverings should continue to be worn.
*If you test positive for COVID-19, you may need to stay where you are until you test negative. You may also need to seek treatment there.
